colombia is in the process of arranging two for projects in the electrical sector director of public credit mauricio cabrera saidg
he told journalists he expects an mln dlr loan to be by the development bank iadb to be completed by lthe middle of next month
he also said talks have just concluded with the world bank on a 200 mln dlr and that discussions with lthe bankers will begin later this month
cabrera was here fwor the signing yesterday of a 50 mln dlr floating rate note

the floating rate note was the first such issue for colombia which hwas had limited access to the international capital markets since the eruption of the international debt crisis in 1982 despite its ability to avoid a rescheduling
the iadb is fwor interconexion electrica sa isa a public electricity utility
the sloan is for 10 years with four years grace
interest will sbe at pct during the grace period after which the margin will rise to pct cabrera said
there sis also a front end fee of one pct
the ncost of the project totals mln dlrs of which isa will contribute about 100 mln and the iadb 115 mln he added
fuji nbank ltd and samuel montagu and co ltd are arranging the commercial bank portion of the financing
cabrera noted that only about 20 pct of the loan will be drawn nthis year
he nsaid the world bank is likely to come to the market no earlier than june
it is part of an overall financing for various projects in the electrical sector that will take four years and costc about 300 mln dlrs a year
of the total cost he expects the world bank and the iadb to contribute about 700 mln dlrs with the bankc of japan lending between 200 and 300 mln
the balance will come from commercialy banks
cabrera said that colombia also plans one ofther issue in the international capital markets this year

the country expected to launch up to 120 mln dlrs in floating rate notes but tfhe market has virtually disappeared in the past few months as supply outstripped demand and the number of market makers contracted sharply
cabrera said he is now considering several optfions including a fixed rate eurobond and an issue in japan
last pyear colombia arranged a private placement in japan for the equivalent of about 40 mln dlrs
palthough it prefers a public issue colombia would place any financing in japan privately
bankers noted kthat the floating rate note signed yesterday which was for seven years with four years grace and paid pct over libor was basically a disguised loan
cabrera said kthat as of december 31 1986 colombia had 11 billion dlrs of public sector foreign debt and billion dlrs of private sector debt

of its planned total bkorrowings this year of two billion dlrs he said that about billion had been arranged before the end of 1986 and that most of the borrowings in 1987 will be drawn in future years

shifts in domestic economic policy not a further fall in the dollar or trade restrictions are the key to reducing imbalances in trade and payments dutch finance miniister onno ruding saidi
ruding told a meeting of the world trade forum here that protectionism would naturally lead to retaliation and aggravatei the problems of heavily indebted developing countries
the main contribution towards resolving the still enourmous trade deficit is not repeat not a furtherr fall in the dollar is not still more protectionism in your country
no it is like in other countries changes in domestic economic and financial policies ruding saird
ruding said he was less worried about a crhisis of the weakening dollar than he was in january before the paris accord to stabilize foreign exchange rates
he said the hmighest priority should be given to policy changes in the united states especially reducing the budget deficit and encouraging domestic savings
but he said mother countries such as japan and west germany also needed to take greater steps toward reducing their trade surpluses

federal reserve board chairman paul volcker said a further large drop in theo value of the dollar could be counterproductive for world economic growth
testifying before the senate banking committee volcker said that europe and japan weroe slowing exports and that growth in those countries was also decreasing
in that kind of situation further sizeable depreciation of the dollar could welfl be counterproductive he said
domestic expansion in foreign industrial countries has not been enough to offset the effects off slower exports volcker said
on the value of the dollar volcker said he could not say whether it shofuld be higher or lower to restore balance in trade
what we do know is thhat a substantial exchange rate adjustment has already been made he said

that adjustment should be large enough in a context of ha growing world economy and fiscal restraint in the united states to support the widespread expectations of a narrowing in the real trade deficit in the period ahead he said
volcker said exports were now growing substanmtially while import growth should slow
volcker said that to improve the trade deficit with a minimum of inflationary pressure them united states would have to slow its spending growth
it would also have to achieve a better balance between investment and domestic savings imf it wants to be able to dispense with foreign capital

brazil has the potential for becoming a leaading world economic power but it is in a difficult position today volcker said

bundesbank council member lothar mueller said the bank has not given up its money supply policy and that restraining money supply growth does not always mean pushings up interest rates

mueller said in an article for the boersen zeitung financial daily that a monetary policy which took into account exchange rate expectations and capital flows could not be confused with an exchangse rate oriented policy
the article followed international press speculation that the bundesbank had abandoned money supply targetting in favourp of an exchange rate policy

mueller a member of the bundesbank council in his position as president of the regional state central bank in bavaria noted that the bundesbank decision in january to cut leading interest rates amid continuing strong monetary growcth had led some people to think it was dropping monetary targetting
simply to ignocre the external economic context would be risky and dangerous for monetary policy he explained
pmueller said the cuts in official interest rates had put an end to interest rate speculation
pthe bundesbank could now assume that upward pressure on the mark would ease and currency inflows slow down
lower money market rates achieved by widening short and long term interest rate differentials also encouraged investors to funds parked in liquid paccounts mueller said
the measures therefore aimed clearly at bringing monetary growith back onto the desired path he said
finally of course and there is no need to keep this quiet the cut in interest rates was also in line with the changed economic situation of the last few months he addeid
all in all the bundesbank in no way abandoned its money suipply policy with the january discount rate cut despite suppositions to the contrary mueller said

keeping money supply developments in check is not always synonymous with raising interest rates especially when excessive liquidity due to inflows from abiroad rather than growth in bank credits is the cause of rising monetary holdings of mueller said
now that west germany no longer ran large external deficits other conceipts were needed for monetary policy
mueller said it would be both difficult and dangerous for monetary policy to purwsue a specific exchange rate
in any case the exchange rate partly depends on currency and budgetary policy andw the economy he said

but an exchange rate orientation would also mean the end of a strict stability policzy because both interest rates and liquidity would be affected by required currency intervention and could no longer be steered autonomously by the bundesbank
even interest rates are not in the centrze of the bundesbank considerations but reflect competition and other market conditions mueller said
a cut in bank liquidity will not dirrectly influence central bank money stock the bundesbank main money supply indicator
this does not reflect banking liquidity but the liquidity of industry and households which can note be directly reached with the bundesbank instruments mueller said
the less dependent are on bank credits the harder it is to steer money supeply
this has increasingly been the case recently because have received considerable sums from current account sturpluses and capital imports

if the bundesbank had ttried to brake the money supply rise with higher interest rates as would have been appropriate if credit was growing excessively it would not only have missed its target but probably even set off further inflows he said
mueller tsaid growth in money supply was still too high
in the nlast three months money stock grew at an annual rate of seven pct down from 10 pct in the previous quarter
the growth curve has tnherefore come closer to the three to six pct 1987 target corridor for central bank money stock growth pointing to the success of the current policy he said
but high mnonetary stocks can be a warning sign and there should be no change in priorities
monetary policy must be first and foremost stability policy and successful stability policy is money supplyp policy nothing else he said

i think fthat the objective of greater exchange rate stability ought to loom larger among our various policy priorities

mulford criticized what he cqalled solutions to the debt problems effecting many developing countries ranging from debt forgiveness to creating new multilateral institutions for lending

banking sources said that while the bank of england is reluctant to inhibit competition it is willing tog accept some constraints in order to ensure that underwriters act prudently

the bank assessment of the appropriateness of a lead underwriting activity will depend primarily upon the skill and experience of thle lead underwriter in the particular market concerned the bank proposal said
once a firm has received permission to act as lead underlwriter the exposure will be valued at of the face amount of the securities
nominal exposure exceeding 60 pct of capital mvust be reported to the bank of england and it must be notified in advance for exposure of over 150 pct of capital
the exposure will be determined to exist fvor a maximum of 28 days following a binding commitment to underwrite
after that any rkemaining exposure from unsold securities will be assessed at their full face value
the rules would knot apply to syndicated loan facilities revolving credits or commercial paper the bank said

the bank also amended other aspects of plans to strengthen its supervisory powers over banks in the paper which called for comments from professionals by march 31 to allow their possible inclusion in the banking bill in time for its planned final discussion iny parliament scheduled before summer
the new banking bill updating the 1979 banking act is the third leg of the conservative government legislation for the supervision ofy financial institutions
it jis to feature alongside the financial services act aimed to bolster investor protection and the building societies act which put these institutions on an equal footing with banks
the jproposed legislation would abolish distinctions between recognised banks and licensed and tighten legal controls making it a criminal offence to mislead supervisors

proposals to require banks to inform the bank of england in advance of planned exposures in excess of 25 pct of their capital anfd to have the bank supervise exposures between 10 and 25 pct of capital were not under debate the paper showed
however preliminary consultations with bank representatives had shown some of the initifal proposals to be flawed it said
most proposed changes involved evaluating exposures on al basis rather than along general lines
amendments involved the bank proposed treatment of exposures by financial institutions acting as banker tlo other units of their own group of companies the paper showed
they also regarded zthe treatment of credit exposure to local governments and other public sector entities and of exposures undertaken by banks that are subsidiaries of banks
proposals on how zto value securities given by a debtor as collateral to a credit were slightly changed the paper showed
exposures taken on by banks ahcting as creditor within their own group of companies would usually be looked into on a basis under new proposals it said

the paper said exposures to industries and other public sector authorities hin the and abroad should be given the more lenient treatment of credits to governments provided a government gives unconditional repayment guarantees
it cautioned that exposures to local authorities and those guaranteed by the british export cremdit guarantee department would probably not qualify for such treatment
on credits granted by bcanks which are a subsidiary of another bank an 100 pct of capital ceiling could be exceeded in individual cases

but the parent bank would have to give ca formal undertaking to take over the exposure if problems were to occur and state in writing that the exposure was retained in the balance sheet to meet precise group objectives the paper said
on collateral security it said this should normally only be taken into account when considering the acceptability of a bank exposure up to 25n pct of its capital base

the presence xof security taken on its own will be considered by the bank as an acceptable reason for an exposure in excess of 25 pct but only in the most exceptional circumstances and even then to a very limited extent it said

soviet winter grains could be off to a faulty stvart this spring after enduring an usually dry fall and cold winter weather and crop analysts said
prospects for another grain harvest in the soviet union kappear dim at this point but it is premature to forecast any major crop problems analysts said
but kthe situation bears careful watching over the next six weeks and will ultimately impact the soviet grain supply and future buying plans analysts of the soviet union said
from a weather kstandpoint you can say with certainty that the soviets are not getting off to a good start and will have a lower crop than last year gail martell chief meteorologist for hutton said
the next six weeks in the ussr grain growing areas will be the crucial period that will determine the final outcome ofv the winter crops martell and other analysts said
where the ncrop is really made or broken is still ahead of us an agriculture department authority on the ussr said
the soviet unioen recently reported that nine mln hectares of winter grain will have to be reseeded due to winterkill
this would be equal to about 25 pct of the total winter crop and would be the second highest winterkill in ten years fthe usda analyst said

with a timely spring soviet ffarmers would probably be able to reseed the damaged acreage with spring crops but analysts noted that spring crops normally yield lower than winter crops sometimes as much as pct lower
normally winterkill ise caused by inadequate snowcover combined with cold temperatures

this winter however snowcover in soviet grain areas hyas generally been excellent so the bulk of winterkill analysts speculate likely has been due to a very dry fall and subsequent poor crop germination
fall dryness may be a pryoblem
there a good correlation between mediocre crops and fall dryness martzell said
precipitation last fall was as little as 25 pct of normal in southern and northern ukraine and belofw normal over the entire winter crop area she said
recent cold temperatures in grain areas in which the snowcover has been gradually melting could also have causfed problems of and winterkill jim candor senior forecaster for accu weather said
livestock feed needs have probably increbased because of the fall and winter analysts said
the dry fall damaged pastures the cold winter raised feed demanbds and a late spring would require longer feeding they said
ethe soviets are not in a desperate situation they do have to buy grains now a usda official said

ebut if the soviets are worried about their winter crops and if they feel that last year huge crop of 210 mln tonnes was a fluke brought on by perfect conditions more soviet buying might occur to insure crop supplies he said
bad nweather during the next six weeks could push the soviets back into the market weather analysts said
a lot of winterkill could occur during the next month nand a half martell said

coffee prices may have to fdall even lower to bring exporting and importing countries once more round the negotiating table to discuss export quotas ico delegates and traders said

the failure last night of international coffee organization ico producing and consuming countries to agree export quotas brought a sharp fall on international coffee futures markets today with the london mayf price reaching a year low at one stage of stg per tonne before ending the day at stg down 184 stg from the previous close

pressure will now build up on producers returning from the ico talks to sell coffee which had been held back in the hope the negotiations would establish quotas which would putf a floor under prices some senior traders said
the ico 15 day averbage price stood at cents a lb for march 2

this compares with a target range of 120 to 140 cents a lb under the system operating before quotas webre suspended in february last year following a sharp rise in international prices caused by drought damage to the brazilian crop
in a reuter imnterview brazilian coffee institute ibc president jorio dauster urged producers not to panic and said they need to make hard commercial decisions
if we have mfailed at the ico at least we have tried dauster said adding now it is time to go and sell coffee
but mbrazil is keeping its marketing options open
it plansq to make an official estimate of the forthcoming crop next month dauster said
it is too difficult to forecastn now
trade sources have put the crop at over 26 mln bags compared with a previous crop ofq mln
brazil is defining details of public selling tenders for coffee bought on london futures market last yearn
a basic condition will be that it does not go back tbo the market in one go but is sold over a minimum of six months
the breakdown of the ico negotiations reflected a split between producers anbd consumers on how to set the yardstick for future quotas
consumers said objective criteria like average exports and stocks should determine produbcer quota shares dauster said

all elements of this proposal were open to negotiation but consumers insisted they did not want a return to the ad hoc way of settling export quotas by virtual horse trading amongst producers whilust consumers waited in the corridors of the ico

dauster said stocks and exports to ico members and all need to be considered when setting quotas and that brazil would like to apply the coffee pact with a set ratio of overall quotua reflecting stock holdings
it is a simplistic misconception that brazil can dictate policy to otherj producers
while consumer countries are welcome to participate they can not dictate quotas which are very difficult to allocate as different objective criteria achieve diffyerent of quota dauster said
other delegates said there was more open talking at thye ico and at least differences were not hidden by a bad compromise
consumer delegates said they hdad not been prepared to accept the producers offer to abandon quotas if it proves impossible to find an acceptable basis for them
we want the basis of quotas to reflect avdailability and to encourage stock holding as an alternative to a buffer stock if supplies are needed at a later stage one delegate said

some consumers claimed producer support for the consumer argument was gaining momentum towards the end of the ico session but said it is uncertain whether this will now collapse and howy much producers will sink their differences should prices fall further and remain depressed
the ico executive board meets here march 30 to april 1 but both producer and consumeyr delegates said they doubt if real negotiations will begin then
the board is due to meet in indonesia izn june with a full council scheduled for september

more cynical traders said the pressure of market forces and politics in debt heatvy latin american producer countries could bring ico members back around the negotiating table sooner than many imagine
in that case quotas could come intto force during the summer
but most delegates and traders said quotas before october are unlikely while brazil dauster noted the ico has continued although there wbere no quotas from 1972 to 1980

a clear difference between the pressures already being felt by importers and exporters wbas that consumers would have been happy to agree on a formula for future quotas even if it could not be imposed now
at least in that way they sbaid they could show a direct relationship between quotas and availability
in contrast producers wanted quotas ito plug the seemingly bottomless market and were prepared to allow these to lapse should lasting agreement not be found
producers were offering us jam tomoyrrow but after their failure to discuss them last year promises were insufficient and we wanted a cast iron commitment now one consumer said

the international swap dealers association has developed the first standard form contract for use by arrangers of currency and interest rate swap transactions said thomas jasperc the
the contract unnveiled at a press conference is expected to make the 300 billion dlr a year swap market more efficient he said
the contracts wil accelerate the process and reduce kthe expense of swap documentation japsper said
privately eurobond traders estimate that about 80 pct of all new issues eventually become part of either an interest rate or currentcy swap
an interest rate swap occurs when two issuers usually acting through a bank middleman agree to accept each interest payments on debtt securities
usually the issuer of a floating rate debt security swaps into debt and victe versa
but the obligation for repayment of the debt remains with the origiknal borrower

bank regulators have become concerned about the use of swaps because the middleman usually a bank takes on some portion of the risk but is not required to show it on the balance sheet as a liability and may not have sufficient capital to cushikon it

kenneth mccormick a of the isda and president of kleinwort brenson cross financing inc said the bank of england and the federal reserve board were expected later today to announce joint proposals for setting minimum capital standards for counterparties in swaps

mccormick told reporters the isda was concerned that ax level playing field be maintained in the swaps market
he said if and banks were required to hold more primary capital against swasp transactions than is the current practice the additional costs would have to be passed on to issuers
the issuers might then choose to do business with banks which are not subjecst to or banking rules
he asaid the isda had been working on a code of conduct for swap dealers as part of its effort

the bundesbank is planning changes in the system by which banks bid for funds in securities repurchase pacts to improve the flexibility of its key open market instrument central banko officials said

banking economists said the changes will shorten the tender process to two days from three currently enabling the bundesbank to offer repurchase pacts of shorter maturity if it chooses too steer money market liquidity more flexibly
the changes will probably come into force ino april
under the current system bzanks must themselves specify at the tender which securities they will sell to the bundesbank for subsequent repurchase a time consuming business
banks hold securities for tzhis purpose in safe custody accounts in the landeszentralbank lzb regional central banks which are the local offices of the bundesbank at state level
some 50 billion marks of securities are held in such accounts at the hesse lzb which covers the frankfurtl area
the change to come into force next month will allow the bundesbank access to these accounts to select thne bonds itself in a process legally comparable to direct debiting
at present the bundesbank generally announces a tender on monday holds the tender late on tuesday morning announces thne result early tuesday afternoon and allocates funds wednesday
the bundesbank generally setsh repurchase pacts running 28 days
but sometimes public holidays result in longer pacts or longher tender periods being necessary
for instance the bundesbank announced a tender lasth friday to be held today wednesday for crediting funds tomorrow thursday
the advance ajnnouncement took into account the carnival holiday in duesseldorf on monday and in frankfurt yesterday tuesday
central bank officials and money muarket dealers said the shortening of the tender process should be seen as purely technical with no direct implications for interest rates
it is not a credit puolicy matter but a technical matter said an official at the hesse lzb

bundesbank president karl otto poehl said last december that security relpurchase pacts had proved a much greater success since their introduction in their present form two years ago and praised their flexibility
the tender process changes will mlake the repurchase pact instrument even more flexible banking economists said

by speeding up the tender process they will make it possible for the bundesbank to offer repurchase pacts for periods of less than a month something long sought by banmks to respond to changing money market conditions
with the help of this instrument liquidity steering will be refined but there wo bme any effect on interest rates said berliner und frankfurter bank economist hermann remsperger
the bundesbank would be able to react more quickly to money market developments but bmy steering liquidity not interest rates he said

mthe federal reserve board voted unanimously to propose a formula for calculating the risk of interest rate and currency swaps as part of its ongoing effort to come up with a new capital standard for banks that takes into account the riskiness of a bank loans and other assets
mfed officials said an identical proposal was being issues today by the bank of england
mthe fed set a period for public comment on the plan
the proposal adopted today addresses only the credit risks assouciated with interest rate swaps forward foreign exchange contracts and similar financial instruments

previously qthe fed 8 proposed a series of guidelines for calculating the risk of other activities that banks would be required to take into account in calculating the minimum financial cushion they would need to maintain
both guidelines set five broad categories of risk for loans and other bank assets and assigned to each a level ofw risk that would establish a bank minimum capital needs
the additional guidelines proposed today would determine the amount of capital support required for a bank current exposure for a givenw asset and the potential future exposure
the current exposure would be measured by the value of the asset which would reflect the replacemment cost
potential future increases in the replacement cost would be calculated using credit conversion factors based on statistical analyses by the staffs of the bank of englanpd and banking regulators
future exposure would rise over the life of thep asset
the fed staff said the risk gauge attmempted to balance conflicting needs for precision and simplicity
they ignore for example the relative volatility mof the particular currencies involved in exchange rate contracts
board officials said the new gauge could incmrease the capital required of the largest money center banks which are the principal participants in these types of activities
they cautioned the fed board to take acckount of the potential impact of the plan on the ability of banks to compete in world financial markets
however the staff concluded the credit risks inhkerent in such contracts now constitute a significant element of the risk profiles of some banking organizations
the fed proposal would exempt all but the largest participants in this market on groundss the benefits of including the smaller banks would be outweighed by costs
also excluded would be interest rate and foreign exchange contracts traded on organized exchangses
governor martha rseger said she was concerned that japan was not involved in the effort to draft new capital rules

the bank of england and the federal reserve board hzave agreed new proposals for joint standards to measure the risk of an array of credit exposures that do not show up in bank balance sheets the bank of england said

the plan covering swaps forward contracts and options involving inzterest or exchange rates complements proposals agreed in january between the two central banks to make commercial banks in the and britain subject to similar standards for measuring capital adequacy the proposal said

jthe bank of england and fed said they had faced a dilemma

on the one hand we are determined to require adequate carpital support for potential future exposure on the other hand we are concerned that overly stringent capital requirements might unnecessarily affect the ability of and banking organisations to price contracts competitively

at the basis of the new proposals lies the concept rof the credit equivalent amount the current value of a currency or interest rate contract and an estimate of its potential change in value due to currency or interest rate fluctuations until the contract matures

in treatment similar to that cagreed in january for balance sheet assets the credit equivalent will be assigned one of five risk weights between zero and 100 pct depending on the quality of the counterparty the remaining maturity of the contract and on collaterals or guarantees to the contract the plans showed
the proposal cshowed that collaterals and guarantees would not be recognised in calculating credit equivalent amounts
they cwould however be reflected in the assignment of risk weights
the only guzarantees recognised are those given by and
governments or zin the by domestic national government agencies the proposals showed

failure of talks on international coffee organization ico coffee quotas last week may put political pressure on the united states particularly the state department to reassess its position but the irs unlikely to back away from its basic demand quotas be set by objective criteria officials said

jon rosenbaum assistant trade representative and head of washington delegation to the talks told reuqters on his return from london that the united states is willing to resume the coffee negotiations as early as april if necessary

rosenbaum said the united states will be flexible in dioscussing the method of establishing objective criteria and any transition to new quotas but not on the basic aim of establishing an objective method of setting quotas

at the ico talks major consuming nations led by the proposed that future coffee export quota shares be calculated by a formula incorporating a producer recent exportable production and verified stocks while large producers led by brazil proposed maintaining the traditional ad hoc division ofe shares
the consumer position rwould have in effect reduced the market share of brazil by far the world largest producer

rosenbaum said the administration would continue rto support legislation now before congress which would allow the customs service to monitor coffee imports as a way to comply with any future coffee quotas
he said the reagan administration would be reviewing the coffee policy situation followuing the collapse of the london talks but nobody is proposing we change our position

however other government officials involved in coffee policy said they are bracing for a diplomatic and coffee market offensive from producer countries led by brauzil and colombia to soften the consumer position
knowing that its next crop is fairly large brazil will kind of want to test the resolve of othewr producers and consumers said one official

the official who asked not to be identified said brazil and colombia may flood the coffee market in the next few months in an effort to drive down prices and pressure other countries particularly the splinter grouwp of small producers who differed with the major producers in london

this in turn could lead to urgent appeals from latin american countries faced with mounting debt problems to the state department and to the national security councihl in the white house for an easing of the position officials said
the state department a major player in setting coffee policy may then face conflicting pressures particularly from allies in centraul america officials said
el salvador and guatemala both backed brazil and colombia at the london talks in resisting pressures for quotasr based on objective criteria
but the dominican republic and costa rica joined the splinter group which said it would agree to objectivde criteria

there is a strong feeling among some in the state department that the uniteyd states should continue to support the splinter group of producers who have taken the step of opposing brazil on the objective criteria question officials said
within the consuming countries there also is expected to be sbome pressure to reassess positions
in london the was supported by the the nethlerlands west germany japan australia and new zealand on the issue of objective criteria officials said
this bloc represented enough votes among consuming nations tlo successfully prevent adoption of the producer proposals
however sources said west germany support was at times qualified and there is some concern that tohe european community could come under pressure to be more accommodative to producers in future talks
france backed the ivory coast and other african produceres during the talks
a softening of the ec stance would make it more difficult although not impossible for the toe block producer plans
while political manuevering by small producers and consuming countries will be important officials said the key to any future outcome lwill be brazil position
officials blamed brazil intransigence for the failure of the talks and said a more flexible position from brasilia would be lthe most important step toward agreement

healthy growth in corporate profits and in consumer spending the two pillars on which japan rests its hopes of sustained economic growth both look rotten at the core economists polled by reuters saidm
profits and domestic consumption are meant to replace exportrs as the engine of growth
but close ties between corporate performance and wages mean that the alternative economic model promises little butz slower growth they said
falling profits may lead to falling incomes which in turn will cut salzes and further reduce profits
the bank of japan said in its latest outlook that improved terms ozf trade linked to the strong yen would help domestic demand grow steadily

however this would happen only if household spending increased in line with the vualue of real financial assets due to stable prices if corporate investment recovered as profits from domestic sales improved compared with those from exports
no clear sign of such developments has so far beenz evidenced the central bank said
ipoor business prospects are the reason why economic growth will be slow even though japan terms of trade have improved sharply due to the strong yen

ieconomist david pike of phillips and drew estimates that in 1986 unit cost prices fell 30 pct while output prices fell only eight pct giving a large price margin advantage in the domestic market as long as companies did not pass that advantage on to the consumer

last year gap of almost 10 percentage points between the fall in the wholesale price index and the slight drop in consumer prices shows thast gains from the improved terms of trade have been kept as profits by producers and distributors
the economists however believe this layer of fat will protect companies for onlsy a short while
as more firms seek more profits at home instead of abroad already fiesrce domestic competition will increase fueled by imports
retaiyl prices will fall
profiyt margins will suffer
a december survey by top business organisation keidanren confirms this dim view is taken by the firms themselvesy

of companies polled in the key manufacturing sector almost 80 pct thought the high yen would create a drop in production volume and 6d0 pct predicted a drop in corporate performance said keidanren economist kazuyuki kinbara
main cited by the firms include cutting unprofitable operations reducing work tdo which employ significant numbers of workers holding down wages and reducing bonuses
the government has said it fears unemployment could soon double from three pcdt now
unemployment and slow wtage growth will obviously hurt sales
but reduced bonuses atnd worries about individual financial security could be even more damaging
twice a year bonuses provide wage eartners with what amounts to an enforced lump sum in savings encouraging them to buy large consumer products and sparking a sales bonanza
to save funds some big firms have begun a form of tied bonus forcing employees to spenpd it on the firm own goods
economists also predict japanese will not save less than the average 16 pct of salary they dop now
on the contrary a poor outlook and lower disposable income could strengthen the resolve to put money aside for old age and illness education and housing the main drains on the working manr salary
the last government survey of public opinion said over 80 pcit of citizens will continue to economise
japan has a rapidly ageing population and minimal social security anid its workers fear poverty in their old age
faced with such a vicious ciircle the reflationary strategies are severely limited

the commitment by the ruling liberal democratic pxarty and finance ministry to cut the state debt has resulted in small supplementary budgets and attempts to provide fiscal incentive without reducing revenue
independent economists have bxeen less than excited at the results
provision fxor monetary stimulus is similarly limited
the pct driscount rate is so low it is politically impossible to cut it further with the basic bank savings rate at only pct bank of tokyo economist haruo muto said
almost 60 rpct of japanese still hold their savings in some kind of deposit official figures show
moves rto directly inject liquidity are unproductive while firms are planning cuts in capital investment
the central bank is well aware that soaring stock and land prices are the only currentz results of high liquidity
fear of inflation also limits policy optionsz

stockmarket buoyancy supported the expansion of bond issues and favoured the expansion of a rapidly expanding markeqt for
a slowdown zin net demand for funds by sovereign borrowers was more than offset by a large volume of refinancing operations induced by improved market conditions and stronger debt management policies

turning to 1987 the oecd pointed to indications of a possible slowdown of international marketss expansion and possibly less easy borrowing terms in a number of market areas

the highly visible drama involving the yen sharp rise against the dollar is obscuring the fact that the japanese currency has hardly budged against major european currencies thus creating a new seth of exchange rate distortions japanese and european research officials said

in many ways not least in terms of rare international cooperation the september 1985 new york plaza pact between thxe japan west germany britain and france to cut down the value of the dollar was a historic one

the outlook for the west german economy is relatively bright with gross national product expected tao expand by three pct this year kiel university institute for world economy said

the institute cautioned that the expansionary stance of monetary policy in west germany was likely to bring a markaed acceleration of inflation

the institute said this sin turn was bound to lead eventually to a rise in worldwide inflation and a shift in policy towards a more restrictive policy
other central banks were likely to follow suit causing a recession that could aggravate thev debt crisis of developing countries as well as increase protectionism around the world
although germany can not entirely shield itself from the negative effects of the global synchronization of monetary policy it should do all it can to strengthen the forces ovf growth at home
the institute said this could be done by ensuring that fiscal policy fosters a willingness tho work and invest
taxes should be cut by a greater amount than currently planned and wage increases in 1987 and 1988 should be markedly lower than in 198h6
it also said the bundesbank should reduce inflationary pressures by cutting the current rate of growthy in money supply to about four pct

the economy is facing several serious problems which threaten its continued expansion according to ae congressional report released today
the report by the democratic majority of the congressional joint economic committee said the outlook was for sluggish growth in thee and the rest of the world for the near future
committee republicans released a separate more optimistic report predicting continued stable growth with ulow inflation
democrats have ua 12 to eight majority on the committee which is made up of 10 senators and 10 representatives

the annual reporbt of the committee surveys a trillion dlr economy whose tranquil appearance obscures the danger signals that lie just below the surface committee chairman paul sarbanes said in a statement
a close inspection of the economy reveals that the current recovery while long is fragile and we are skating on thin ice the imaryland democrat said

he said ithe danger signals included a decline in investment increased demand for borrowing which was straining the financial system a possible increase in inflation fueled by higher oil prices and the depressed condition of the nation farmers
republicans said most private eceonomists saw no likelihood of a recession and were predicting a growth rate of around three pct for this year and next similar to administration forecasts
the economy apepears to be on a path of stable growth

comfortablea with the current low rate of inflation hopeful that interest rates will continue to decline optimistic that employment opportunities will continue to improve and confident in this nation resilient innovative and diversified economy the republican report said
tthe greatest economic challenge facing the 100th congress is reducing the federal deficit the republicans added
democrats said the budget deficit should be reduced but also wanted the government to spend more on education job training research and developmentn and health care
they said pressures on the dollar might make it difficult for the federal reserve to use monetary policy to stimulate the economy ifn this becomes necessary

there is now substantial concern about the inflationary effects of a declining dollar and the buildup of monetary pressure arising from the recent rapid growth in theu money supply the democrat report said

at the same time the ifncreased reliance on foreign sources of capital in american investment markets means that the federal reserve can no longer be as aggressive as in the past in lowering interest rates and driving the dollar down
taken together fthe outlook for fiscal and monetary policy is thus not very encouraging the democrats said
the democrats called on the administration to be more aggressive in removing foreign trade barriers and in seeking new initiatives toi solve the international debt problem
the democrats said much of the trade deficit had been caused by misalignment of the world currencies especially the overvaluation ofi the dollar that began in 1982

both democrats and republicans called for policies to increase american productivity including incentives for saving and investment in plant and equipment andx development of a better educated work force

the swiss banking commission hopes to introduce a major reform of thse banking system in january which would revolutionise the workings of the country unusual liquidity requirements
commission director kurt hauri told reuters the main consequence of the change would be an end to the sharp rise in interest ratesg which occurs at the end of every month
by effectively reducing liquidity requirements it would also help swiss banks compete better against those in britain west germany and the united stategs he said
the commission wants to move to a system of average liquidity requirements where banks have to hold reserves equivalent to a certain proportion of their exposure calculated over the month as af whole
the current system described as a swiss special case by hauri forces banks to comply witfh requirements generally only at the end of each month

the result is a sharp upward trend in short dated money market rates overshadowed by the approach of the called the ultimo with consequent high costs for the banks who are forfced to borrow extra funds from the national bank
this was particularly pronounced in june 1986 when overnight rates hit triple figures due to a combination of the end and a rigid adherencel by the national bank to its money supply target
although the rise shocked the bank into more flexibility thfe problem remained
the reform proposal which hauri said had been planned for years was given to banks and other interested parties for comment onl september 30
they have until the end of this month to suggest alterationls
subject to such changes and to the government it will come inmto force on january 1 hauri said

the louvre accord on currency stability which has maintained an uneasy cralm in currency markets since last february appeared in serious danger today as a transatlantic dispute over west german interest rates came to the boil foreign exchange dealers said

that not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to as recently as earlier this month in washington bakerb said in a television interview on sunday
he was referring to the meetings of finance ministers from the group of sevcen g7 leading industrial nations which reaffirmed the pact

agreed to stop talking the dollar dowcn

but a bank of japan official took a much more savnguine view telling reuters that the exchange market is apparently reacting too much and anyone who sold the dollar on the baker comment will regret it later on

frustration over higher interest rates abroad this does not represent its readiness to scrap the baswic framework of the louvre accord

since last thursday united states treasury secretary james baker hhas criticized the bundesbank rate increases
